page.title: 02LAUGHARNE'S HISTORY
page.content: Laugharne developed from a Celtic hillfort "Abercorran". In Llandawke Church is a gravestone with mixed Ogham/Roman inscription. In the Church of St Martin are bones of the Beaker people found locally, a 10th Century Celtic cross and an oriel window with the head of Edward III, about 1350, in the nave. Laugharne Castle has early 13th Century towers and Tudor additions. In about 1307 Charter given by Sir Gwydo de Brione to Laugharne Corporation, document extant. Also 2 original documents detailing the 1568 Hundred Court Meeting in "le guilde hall" and the "Book of Survey 1592 of the Castle Lordship and Manor of Tallaugharn". The Custom Officers Book of 1817 lists cargoes to Ireland from Laugharne as bark, grain, butter and cheese. Stone was taken out and coal brought in before lorries were used.
